## Description
Design the complete database schema and domain models to support all game mechanics.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create entity relationship diagram (ERD)
- [ ] Define User entity
- [ ] Define Game entity
- [ ] Define Round entity
- [ ] Define PlayerSession entity
- [ ] Define Hand entity
- [ ] Define Card entity (as value object)
- [ ] Define Trick entity
- [ ] Define Score/PointHistory entity
- [ ] Define relationships and foreign keys
- [ ] Document data validation rules
- [ ] Define indexes for performance
- [ ] Plan data archival strategy

## Entity Definitions

### User
- Id (Guid)
- Username (unique, 3-20 chars)
- Email (unique)
- PasswordHash
- DisplayName
- Avatar URL
- Created At
- Last Login
- Statistics (games played, wins, total points scored)

### Game
- Id (Guid)
- CreatedBy (UserId)
- Status (Waiting, InProgress, Completed, Abandoned)
- MaxPlayers (2-5)
- Current Dealer Index
- Current Round Number
- Created At
- Started At
- Completed At

### Round
- Id (Guid)
- GameId (FK)
- Round Number
- DealerUserId (FK)
- PartyPlayerUserId (FK)
- TrumpSuit (Hearts, Diamonds, Clubs, Spades)
- TrumpSelectedBeforeDealing (bool)
- TrickValue (1, 2, or 4)
- CurrentTrickNumber
- Status (Dealing, TrumpSelection, CardExchange, Playing, Completed)
- StartedAt
- CompletedAt

### PlayerSession
- Id (Guid)
- GameId (FK)
- UserId (FK)
- Position (0-4)
- CurrentPoints
- IsActive (playing this round)
- ConsecutiveRoundsOut (0-2)
- JoinedAt
- LeftAt

### Hand
- Id (Guid)
- RoundId (FK)
- PlayerSessionId (FK)
- Cards (JSON array of Card objects)

### Trick
- Id (Guid)
- RoundId (FK)
- TrickNumber (1-5)
- LeadPlayerSessionId (FK)
- WinnerPlayerSessionId (FK)
- CardsPlayed (JSON array)
- CompletedAt

### ScoreHistory
- Id (Guid)
- GameId (FK)
- PlayerSessionId (FK)
- RoundId (FK)
- PointsChange (can be negative)
- PointsAfter
- Reason (TrickWon, Penalty, GameWon)
- CreatedAt

## Acceptance Criteria
- ERD is complete and validated
- All entities support game rules
- Relationships maintain data integrity
- Schema is normalized appropriately
- Indexes support common query patterns

Related to #2
title: Design database schema and domain models

## Description
Create a comprehensive game design document covering all rules, mechanics, and gameplay flow.

## Tasks
- [ ] Document complete game rules from SobeSobe.md
- [ ] Create player interaction flow diagrams
- [ ] Define all game states and state transitions
- [ ] Document edge cases and special scenarios
- [ ] Create glossary of Portuguese game terms
- [ ] Add gameplay examples with step-by-step walkthroughs
- [ ] Document scoring calculations with examples
- [ ] Define validation rules for game actions
- [ ] Create game balance analysis
- [ ] Add FAQ section for common rule questions

## Key Rules to Document
1. **Setup Phase**
   - Player count (2-5, optimal 5)
   - Deck composition (40 cards)
   - Card ranking system
   - Initial point distribution (20 points each)

2. **Round Phase**
   - Dealer rotation (counter-clockwise)
   - Card dealing sequence (2 cards, then 3 more)
   - Trump suit selection rules
   - Player opt-in/opt-out rules
   - Card exchange mechanism (up to 3 cards)

3. **Trick-Taking Phase**
   - Following suit rules
   - Trump card rules
   - Cutting (cortar) rules
   - Ace of trump mandatory play rule
   - Trump escalation rule

4. **Scoring Phase**
   - Trick valuation (1, 2, or 4 points)
   - Point calculation rules
   - Penalty for no tricks (5, 10, or 20 points)
   - Double penalty for party player
   - Win condition (first to 0 points)
   - Prize calculation (5 cents per remaining point)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Document is comprehensive and unambiguous
- All rules from original specification are included
- Edge cases are clearly documented
- Examples clarify complex rules
- Portuguese terms are explained

Related to #2
title: Write comprehensive game rules documentation

## Description
Set up .NET Aspire for local development orchestration and simplified cloud deployment.

## Tasks
- [ ] Install .NET Aspire workload: `dotnet workload install aspire`
- [ ] Create Aspire AppHost project: `SobeSobe.AppHost`
- [ ] Configure API service in AppHost
- [ ] Configure SQLite database connection
- [ ] Setup service discovery
- [ ] Configure environment variables
- [ ] Add health checks for all services
- [ ] Configure Aspire dashboard
- [ ] Document Aspire usage for team
- [ ] Create `launchSettings.json` for easy startup

## AppHost Configuration
```csharp
var builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

// Add SQLite database
var sqliteDb = builder.AddSqlite("gamedb")
    .WithDataVolume();

// Add backend API
var api = builder.AddProject<Projects.SobeSobe_Api>("api")
    .WithReference(sqliteDb)
    .WithExternalHttpEndpoints();

// Add Angular frontend (in development)
var frontend = builder.AddNpmApp("frontend", "../frontend")
    .WithReference(api)
    .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 4200, env: "PORT")
    .WithExternalHttpEndpoints()
    .PublishAsDockerFile();

builder.Build().Run();
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Can run entire application with `dotnet run` in AppHost project
- Aspire dashboard shows all running services with health status
- Services can communicate via service discovery
- Environment variables are properly configured
- Documentation explains how to use Aspire for development

Related to #1
title: Setup .NET Aspire for local development
